results:
Based on my search results, I can provide comprehensive information about "Folwark zwierzęcy" (Animal Farm), censorship in communist Poland (PRL), samizdat/second circulation publishing, and Teresa Jeleńska's role:

## Teresa Jeleńska and Her Translation

Teresa "Rena" Jeleńska (née Skarżyńska, born March 22, 1890 in Jedwabne, died 1969 in Dijon) was a literature translator and journalist.(no content)She met George Orwell while working at the London-based "Dziennik Polski," which led to her becoming the translator of his works. In 1945, "Folwark zwierzęcy" was published in London in Jeleńska's translation.(no content)Teresa Jeleńska's translation was published at the turn of 1946 and 1947 in London by the League of Poles Abroad.(no content)This was the first translation of Animal Farm into a Slavic language – in fact, into any language!

## Censorship and Underground Publishing in Communist Poland

Until the fall of the communist system in Poland in 1989, this was a novel banned by censorship – its first official domestic edition appeared only in 1988.(no content)From 1979, however, it was published multiple times as reprints from emigre editions by independent publishers – the so-called "second circulation."

### Key Underground Publishers

The book was published by Niezależna Oficyna Wydawnicza (Independent Publishing House); Zapis and Puls in Warsaw in 1979.(no content)This was a samizdat edition.(no content)The book was also published by "po prostu bis" publishing house (in cooperation with the Constitution of May 3rd Publishing House - a second circulation publisher from the sixteen months of Solidarity period - a reprint from the "ODNOWA" London 1974 edition), Kraków (February) 1981.

## The Second Circulation (Drugi Obieg)

Second circulation publishing operated in Poland from 1976-90, initially by emerging independent organizations (e.g., KSS "KOR," KPN), and from 1977 also by independent publishers (e.g., NOWA, Krąg) and environmental groups (student, workplace, professional).(no content)It is estimated that in Poland from December 13, 1981 to the end of 1988, approximately 4,500 titles of books and brochures and about 2,000 press titles were published in the second circulation.(no content)An important event was the establishment in 1977 of the first professional publishing house operating outside the reach of censorship, the Independent Publishing Office (NOWa).

## 1989 and the End of Communist Censorship

The year 1989 marked the end of communist rule in Poland. The novel was banned by censorship almost until the fall of the communist system in Poland in 1989 – its first official domestic edition appeared only in 1988.

The underground publishing of "Folwark zwierzęcy" in Poland served as both a literary achievement and a form of political resistance, with Teresa Jeleńska's translation becoming the standard version used in samizdat editions throughout the communist period.
